messageBody:
Radiya wrote:
> Hi,
>
> I have written a method which displays integers on the screen (its a
> for loop and i have a println statement in it).
>
> can i create a junit test case for this method? if so how do i check
> the correct output.

This is a commonly-asked question, so search the archives of this group
for more detail.

Your production code probably does this:

class MyClass ...
myMethod() {
System.out.println("aksdjfhadlkfgjh");
}
}

We want to change this to something like

myMethod() {
console("aslfdkjhasdf");
}

console(String text) {
System.out.println(text);
}

Now, in our test, we can subclass MyClass and override console() to do
something other than write to the console.

myTest() {
StringWriter output = new StringWriter();
final PrintWriter out = new PrintWriter(output);
writer = new MyClass(...) {
public void console(String text) {
out.println(text);
}
};

writer.myMethod();
assertEquals("Expected output\n", output.toString());
}

In this case, I chose to write to a StringWriter, because I can ask it
for the text written to it as a string. Very convenient.

> also how do i create a test case to check the command line params
> passed.

What do you want to test here? Java and the shell work together to parse
this:

run -a -b -c

into this:

String[] {"-a", "-b", "-c"}

...so what are you afraid doesn't work?
